1.title: Chapter 1: Introduction
1.content:
Chapter 1: Introduction

**Translation from the Classical Chinese Original** Based on Kumarajiva's Translation (後秦鳩摩羅什譯) Scholarly English Translation with Philosophical and Scientific Apparatus --- Thus have I heard.¹ At one time, the Buddha was dwelling at Mount Gṛdhrakūṭa near the city of Rājagṛha,² together with a great assembly of twelve thousand bhikṣus.³ All of these practitioners had attained the state of Arhat—having exhausted all outflows of mental affliction, having eliminated all defilements, having realized their own ultimate benefit, having severed all bonds of conditioned existence, and having attained complete freedom of mind.⁴ Their names are recorded as follows: Ājñātakauṇḍinya, Mahākāśyapa, Uruvilvākāśyapa, Gayākāśyapa, Nadīkāśyapa, Śāriputra, Mahāmaudgalyāyana, Mahākātyāyana, Aniruddha, Kapphiṇa, Gavāṃpati, Revata, Pilindavatsa, Bakkula, Mahākauṣṭhila, Nanda, Sundarananda, Pūrṇamaitrāyaṇīputra, Subhūti, Ānanda, and Rāhula—great Arhats of this caliber, well known throughout all communities of practitioners.⁵ --- Furthermore, there were also two thousand persons⁶ among both those still in training and those who had completed their training. The bhikṣuṇī Mahāprajāpatī was present together with her retinue of six thousand bhikṣuṇīs.⁷ Yaśodharā, the mother of Rāhula, was also present with her retinue.⁸ Additionally, there were eighty thousand Bodhisattva-Mahāsattvas,⁹ all of whom had become irreversible in their aspiration toward the attainment of anuttara-samyak-saṃbodhi (supreme perfect enlightenment).¹⁰ All had attained the dharaṇī¹¹—the power to retain and preserve teaching—and possessed eloquence in joyful exposition. They had already turned the irreversible Dharma wheel,¹² spreading teachings that cannot be reversed or overturned. These Bodhisattvas had made offerings to innumerable hundreds of thousands of Buddhas, and in the presence of all these Buddhas they had planted deep roots of virtue. They were constantly praised by all Buddhas on account of their devotion and...

Thereupon, the Bodhisattva Maitreya, wishing to restate this meaning in verse form, spoke the following inquiry:
> *O Mañjuśrī!*
> *Why does the Guide,*
> *From the white hair between his brows,*
> *Universally illuminate with great light?*

2.title: Chapter 2: Skillful Means
2.content:
Chapter 2: Skillful Means

**Translation from the Classical Chinese Original** Based on Kumarajiva's Translation (後秦鳩摩羅什譯) Scholarly English Translation with Philosophical and Scientific Apparatus --- At that time, the World-Honored One, having emerged from meditation with composed serenity, addressed Śāriputra:¹ \"The wisdom of the Buddhas, the Tathāgatas, is infinitely profound and immeasurable. The gateway to this wisdom is difficult to comprehend and difficult to enter—beyond the capacity of all Śrāvakas (disciples) and Pratyekabuddhas (solitary awakeners) to understand. Why is this? \"The Buddhas have approached and made offerings to hundreds of thousands of billions of Tathāgatas beyond number. They have completely practiced the infinite dharmic pathways of all the Buddhas. With courageous diligence, their renown has spread universally. They have accomplished teachings utterly unprecedented and extraordinary.² \"Their teachings, adapted to circumstances and conditions, are of meaning (arthas) most difficult to comprehend. Śāriputra, since my own attainment of Buddhahood, I have employed innumerable causes and conditions, boundless parables and illustrations, and infinite skilful means (upayā) to guide and transform all beings, enabling them to transcend all forms of attachment and clinging.³ Why is this? \"The Tathāgata has completely perfected the transcendent wisdom and vision of skilful means (upaya-jñāna-darsana). Śāriputra, the Tathāgata's wisdom and vision is boundless and vast, profound and far-reaching, infinite and unobstructed. His supernatural powers, fearlessness, meditative concentrations, liberations, and samadhis extend into the infinite and reach to the limit. The Tathāgata has accomplished teachings utterly unprecedented. \"Śāriputra, the Tathāgata is able to make distinctions among the various dharmas and to discourse skillfully upon them, employing words gentle and soft that bring joy to the hearts of all beings.⁴ Śāriputra, in essential summary, the Tathāgata has accompli...

The World-Honored One, wishing to restate this meaning, then spoke in verse:
> *The Lord of Sages cannot be measured—*
> *By all the devas and all people,*
> *All classes of sentient beings,*
> *None have the capacity to know the Buddha.*
>

3.title: Chapter 3: Parables
3.content:
Chapter 3: Parables

**Translation from the Classical Chinese Original** Based on Kumarajiva's Translation (後秦鳩摩羅什譯) Scholarly English Translation with Philosophical and Scientific Apparatus --- At that time, Śāriputra, overflowing with joy and delight, immediately rose from his seat, pressed his palms together in salutation, gazed upon the Buddha's face with reverent attention, and addressed the Buddha: \"Now, having heard this dharma-sound from the World-Honored One, my heart overflows with joy and I have experienced what has never been experienced before. Why is this? \"In ancient times, when I heard from the Buddha such a teaching as this, I saw that the various Bodhisattvas received prophecies of Buddhahood, yet I and my companions were not included in these events. I deeply sorrowed within myself, feeling that I had lost the infinite wisdom of the Tathāgata.¹ \"World-Honored One, I have often dwelt alone in mountain forests and beneath trees, whether sitting or walking, constantly entertaining this thought: 'We have all entered into the dharma-nature equally—why then does the Tathāgata appear to guide us through the small vehicle?' This fault lies with us, not with the World-Honored One. Why is this? \"Had we expected the teaching of that which would enable us to achieve anuttara-samyak-saṃbodhi, we would surely have been liberated through the great vehicle. However, we did not understand the skilful means of adaptive teaching according to circumstances. Upon first hearing the Buddha's teaching, we encountered it and immediately generated faith, contemplated it, and claimed realization. \"World-Honored One, since ancient times I have continuously and throughout day and night reproached myself. Yet now, having heard from the Buddha teachings never before heard, unprecedented dharmas, I have severed all doubt and regret. My body and mind are at peace, my heart is utterly tranquil. Today I truly understand that I am a Buddha-child, born from the Buddha's mouth, born from the dharma, and p...

Then Śāriputra, wishing to restate this meaning, spoke in verse:
> *Having heard this dharma-sound,*
> *I have obtained what was never before experienced,*
> *My heart overflows with great joy,*
> *And all my nets of doubt have been severed.*
>

4.title: Chapter 4: Faith and Understanding
4.content:
Chapter 4: Faith and Understanding

**Translation from the Classical Chinese Original** Based on Kumarajiva's Translation (後秦鳩摩羅什譯) Scholarly English Translation with Philosophical and Scientific Apparatus --- At that time, the wise Subhūti, Mahākātyāyana, Mahākāśyapa, and Mahāmaudgalyāyana, having heard from the Buddha this unprecedented teaching, with the World-Honored One granting prophecy of anuttara-samyak-saṃbodhi to Śāriputra, their hearts were moved with wonder and delight. They immediately rose from their seats, straightened their robes, uncovered their right shoulders in respectful posture, knelt upon their right knees, unified their minds by placing their palms together in reverent salutation, bowed deeply in respect, gazed upon the Buddha's countenance with undivided attention, and addressed the Buddha: \"World-Honored One, we are elders among the assembled monks, advanced in age, and we have long believed that we had already attained nirvāṇa and had no further capacity for spiritual attainment. We harbored no aspiration to advance toward anuttara-samyak-saṃbodhi. \"World-Honored One, in ages past when you taught the dharma at length, we sat in the assembly, but our bodies were weary and lethargic. We contemplated only emptiness, signlessness, and non-activity. Regarding the Bodhisattva dharma—the display of supernatural powers, the purification of Buddha-lands, and the perfection of sentient beings—our hearts did not delight in these teachings. Why was this? \"The World-Honored One caused us to escape from the three worlds and attain the realization of nirvāṇa. Moreover, at this time we are advanced in age. Toward the Buddha's teaching and transformation of Bodhisattvas aspiring to anuttara-samyak-saṃbodhi, we have not generated even a single thought of joy. \"Yet now, before the Buddha, we have heard the prophecy that we too shall attain anuttara-samyak-saṃbodhi as Śrāvakas (voice-hearers). Our hearts are extremely joyful—we have experienced what we had never experienced before. We did not a...

Then Mahākāśyapa, wishing to restate this meaning, spoke in verse. The extended verse parallels and reinforces the parable in poetic form, concluding with key affirmations:
> *We hear the Buddha's teaching,*
> *With joy and delight exceeding measure,*
> *We have obtained what was never before obtained.*
> *The Buddha proclaimed that voice-hearers,*
> *Shall become Buddhas,*

5.title: Chapter 5: Medicinal Herbs
5.content:
Chapter 5: Medicinal Herbs

--- The Medicinal Herbs parable completes the foundational teaching arc initiated in Chapters 2-4. Where Chapter 2 established the One Buddha Vehicle as the ultimate reality underlying apparent multiplicity, Chapter 3 showed how the Buddha employs skillful means to guide beings to safety, and Chapter 4 demonstrated how beings gradually recognize their inherent Buddha-nature, **Chapter 5 now reveals the principle governing this process: the Buddha's single teaching is like a universal rain that nourishes all beings according to their nature and capacity.** This chapter addresses a crucial question implicit in the previous teachings: If the dharma is truly one, and all beings possess Buddha-nature, how do we account for the evident differences in beings' spiritual attainment and the varying paths they follow? The answer lies not in the dharma itself, but in the *differential capacity of recipients*—a principle with profound implications for understanding both Buddhist metaphysics and contemporary systems theory. --- At this point in the assembly, the Buddha turns directly to Mahākāśyapa, one of the great disciples, and affirms what has been taught: > \"Excellent! Excellent, Mahākāśyapa. You have spoken well of the Tathāgata's true virtues. Indeed, the Tathāgata possesses measureless, inconceivable merits that could not be exhausted even if explained throughout countless kalpas. Mahākāśyapa, understand this: the Tathāgata is the sovereign of all dharmas. Whatever the Tathāgata proclaims is never false. Through wisdom and skillful means, the Tathāgata expounds all dharmas, and every dharma taught reaches the domain of all-knowing wisdom.\"¹ This affirmation accomplishes several things simultaneously. First, it establishes the Buddha's omniscience—not as magical knowledge, but as complete understanding of the nature of reality and the conditions for liberation. Second, it emphasizes that this understanding is expressed through *wisdom and skillful means*—the pedagogical me...

The Buddha now speaks in verse to elaborate and emphasize the central points:
> *"The Dharma King who breaks all fixed views*
> *Appears within the world,*
> *And in accord with beings' nature*
> *Speaks the dharma in countless ways.*
> *The Honored Tathāgata,*

6.title: Chapter 6: Prophecies
6.content:
Chapter 6: Prophecies

Chapter 6: Prophecies (授記品第六) -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- With Chapter 5 having established the universal principle by which all beings receive the dharma according to their capacity, Chapter 6 now enacts this principle at the particular level: individual disciples receive explicit prophecies of their future Buddhahood. This chapter marks a crucial transformation in the Lotus Sutra's narrative. What was taught theoretically—that all possess Buddha-nature and will eventually attain enlightenment—is now proclaimed individually, directly, and ceremonially. The chapter serves multiple functions simultaneously: 1. Doctrinal Proclamation: It explicitly contradicts the earlier limited teaching that śrāvakas (direct disciples) reach final nirvana without further development. Here the Buddha declares all his great disciples will become Buddhas. 2. Experiential Validation: The disciples' emotional response (trembling, weeping with joy) shows that hearing one's own prophecy activates a transformative realization that theoretical knowledge about Buddha-nature could not produce. 3. Individual Variation within Universal Truth: Each prophecy differs—different Buddha-names, different Buddha-lands, different numbers of disciples and Bodhisattvas—yet all fulfill the same underlying truth. This illustrates perfectly the Medicinal Herbs principle: one dharma manifesting infinitely according to individual natures.¹ 4. Establishment of Pattern: This chapter initiates a pattern that will dominate Chapters 8-12, establishing that prophecy-giving is the Buddha's central activity in responding to disciples' readiness. ¹ Textual Function [Structure and Rhetoric]: The chapter's repetitive structure (prophecy announced, elaborated in prose, elaborated in verse, then repeated for next disciple) creates a hypnotic rhythm that reinforces the principle through form. The reader experiences the one-yet-many quality directly. --- The Buddha addresse...

The Buddha then elaborates in verse to emphasize and amplify:
"Listen, all monks, I declare to you With the Buddha-eye, I see Mahākāśyapa. In the future world, after countless kalpas, He shall become a Buddha.
In that future age, he shall encounter Three hundred million billion Buddhas, Making supreme offerings with pure conduct, For the attainment of Buddha-wisdom.
Having offered to the Unsurpassed, Two-Footed One, And cultivated all supreme wisdom, In his final existence, he shall become a Buddha. (lines 1715-1721)
The verse shifts focus subtly from the cosmic scope ("three hundred million billion Buddhas") to the internality of Mahākāśyapa's practice ("pure conduct," "Buddha-wisdom"). It emphasizes that becoming a Buddha is not magical transformation but the culmination of genuine spiritual practice—"cultivating all supreme wisdom" over infinite time.
The verse then describes the Buddha-realm itself:

7.title: Chapter 7: Phantom City
7.content:
Chapter 7: Phantom City

--- **Chapter 7 stands at the apex of the Lotus Sutra's doctrinal structure.** Where previous chapters have established the principles of skillful means (Chapter 2), demonstrated them through parables (Chapters 3-5), and proclaimed them through prophecies (Chapter 6), **Chapter 7 now reveals the ultimate purpose of skillful means and explains the relationship between what seemed like final goals and what is actually ultimate truth.** The Phantom City parable is the most architecturally complex parable in the Lotus Sutra. It operates on multiple levels simultaneously: 1. **Narrative Level**: A guide leads travelers through a dangerous journey, helps them rest at a phantom city, then reveals the true destination. 2. **Metaphorical Level**: The Buddha is the guide; the three vehicles are the phantom city; Buddhahood is the treasure. 3. **Metaphysical Level**: The parable reveals that what appears to be completion (nirvana as understood in limited teachings) is actually a stage within a greater completion (Buddhahood). 4. **Pedagogical Level**: The parable justifies the Buddha's use of different teachings for different beings—it's not deception but compassionate guidance using whatever means will work. This chapter transforms everything that came before. Readers must now reinterpret the three vehicles, the concept of nirvana, the meaning of arhat-achievement, and the true relationship between limited teachings and ultimate truth.¹ ¹ **Hermeneutical Crisis [Interpretive Significance]**: The Phantom City parable creates what hermeneuticists call an \"interpretive crisis.\" Readers must reinterpret all previous teachings in light of this new revelation. This radical reframing is intentional—the text is designed to shock readers into new understanding. --- The Buddha begins with an extraordinary temporal introduction: > \"The Buddha told the monks: 'Incalculably long ago, beyond a boundless and inconceivable number of immeasurable aeons, there was a Buddha named Great Penetrat...

The Buddha then elaborates the parable in extended verse, emphasizing its cosmic significance:
> *"The Great Penetrating Wisdom Victory Buddha*
> *Sat ten kalpas at the enlightenment seat,*
> *Yet the dharmas of Buddhahood did not appear.*
> *Unable to attain supreme enlightenment,*
> *Celestial beings and dragon-kings,*

8.title: Chapter 8: Five Hundred Disciples
8.content:
Chapter 8: Five Hundred Disciples

--- **Chapter 8 extends the prophecy-giving initiated in Chapter 6 to encompass all five hundred śrāvakas (direct disciples) assembled before the Buddha.** Where Chapter 6 singled out the greatest disciples and Chapter 7 revealed the metaphysical justification for skillful means, **Chapter 8 now demonstrates that the promise of Buddhahood extends universally—not just to exceptional individuals, but to all who have heard and accepted the dharma.** This chapter introduces one of the Lotus Sutra's most moving parables: the **Pearl in the Garment**—a teaching that illuminates how beings already possess Buddha-nature yet fail to recognize it, and how the Buddha's revelation of this hidden treasure transforms their self-understanding. The chapter accomplishes: 1. **Prophecy for Furūṇa** (富樓那), the foremost in preaching and teaching 2. **Collective prophecy for five hundred arhats**, all becoming the Buddha \"Universal Illumination\" 3. **The Pearl in the Garment parable**, showing beings' hidden treasure 4. **Expansion of prophetic vision** to include all beings capable of hearing the dharma¹ ¹ **Narrative Strategy [Universal Extension]**: The pattern of gradually expanding the circle of prophecy (individuals → groups → all present → future beings) reflects a fundamental Lotus Sutra strategy: moving from particular to universal while maintaining concrete particularity. --- The chapter opens with Furūṇa (富樓那), traditionally known as the foremost disciple in preaching and explaining the dharma: > \"At that time, Furūṇa Maitrayaṇīputra, having heard from the Buddha these teachings of wisdom and skillful means, the adapted teaching according to circumstance, and hearing that prophecies of supreme enlightenment were granted to the great disciples, and hearing of past-life causes and conditions, and hearing of the Buddhas' great autonomous miraculous power—he gained what had never been obtained before, his heart became pure and elated. He rose from his seat, approached the Buddha,...

The Buddha then elaborates in verse:
> *"The monk Ājñātakauṇḍinya*
> *Shall encounter immeasurable Buddhas,*
> *After immeasurable aeons,*
> *Attain perfect enlightenment.*
> *Ever emitting great light,*

9.title: Chapter 9: Learning and Unlearning Disciples
9.content:
Chapter 9: Learning and Unlearning Disciples

--- **Chapter 9 extends the prophecy-giving further, now addressing two crucial figures and a large group: Ānanda (the Buddha's cousin and primary attendant), Rāhula (the Buddha's biological son), and the two thousand learning and unlearning disciples.** The chapter accomplishes several things simultaneously: 1. **Honors key disciples through prophecy**: Ānanda as the dharma-keeper and Rāhula as the eternal son 2. **Addresses questions about fairness**: Why do śrāvakas (disciples of limited path) receive such exalted prophecies? 3. **Reveals original aspiration**: Shows that all beings' ultimate destiny was determined by their original vows, not by present limited understanding 4. **Demonstrates collective prophecy**: The two thousand disciples receive identical prophecies, affirming universal equality 5. **Anticipates future concerns**: Explains why the Buddha's prophecies to disciples might seem to contradict earlier teachings¹ This chapter completes the pattern of expanding prophecies from individuals (Ch. 6) → groups (Ch. 8) → larger groups with representatives (Ch. 9). By Chapter 10, prophecies will extend to ALL beings who hear even a single verse of the Lotus Sutra. ¹ **Narrative Progression [Systematic Expansion]**: The pattern of expanding prophecies serves multiple functions: it demonstrates universality, addresses natural questions, and progressively removes boundaries around who is \"worthy\" of Buddhahood. --- The chapter opens with Ānanda and Rāhula making their own request: > \"At that time, Ānanda and Rāhula thought to themselves: 'We constantly contemplate—if we were to receive prophecy, would this not be excellent?' They immediately rose from their seats, approached the Buddha, prostrated their heads to his feet, and together addressed the Buddha, saying: 'World-Honored One, we too should have a share in this. We have only the Tathāgata as our refuge.² > Moreover, we are known throughout the entire world of gods, humans, and asuras. Ānanda constantly ...

The Buddha elaborates in verse:
> *"When I was a prince,*
> *Rāhula was my eldest son,*
> *Now that I have attained the Buddha-path,*
> *He receives the dharma as the dharma-heir.*
> *In future worlds,*

10.title: Chapter 10: Dharma Teacher
10.content:
Chapter 10: Dharma Teacher

--- **Chapter 10 represents the most radical expansion of the prophecy principle: the Buddha extends the guarantee of Buddhahood to ALL beings who hear even a single verse or sentence of the Lotus Sutra, making prophecy universal and present rather than particular and future.** This chapter accomplishes several revolutionary things simultaneously: 1. **Universalizes Prophecy**: All beings hearing the sutra—now or in the future—receive the prophecy of Buddhahood 2. **Valorizes the Dharma-Teacher**: Establishes those who teach/preserve/practice the sutra as worthy of supreme reverence 3. **Makes the Text Sacred**: The Lotus Sutra itself becomes the dharma-teacher, carrying the Buddha's presence 4. **Transforms Future Time**: Makes the moment of hearing the sutra—whether in the Buddha's presence or centuries later—a direct encounter with enlightenment 5. **Creates a Dharma-Community**: All practitioners become participants in the Buddha's eternal teaching-activity¹ The central assertion is extraordinary: **Hearing even one verse of the Lotus Sutra is sufficient for guaranteed Buddhahood.** This means enlightenment is not distant or difficult but immediately accessible through the dharma. ¹ **Metaphysical Simultaneity [Temporal Transcendence]**: The assertion that future hearing of the sutra is equivalent to present hearing suggests that time is not the fundamental dimension of reality. What matters is the encounter with the dharma, whenever it occurs. --- The chapter opens with the Buddha addressing the Bodhisattva Medicine King (藥王菩薩): > \"At that time, the World-Honored One, through the Bodhisattva Medicine King, addressed eighty thousand great Bodhisattvas: 'Medicine King, do you see in this great assembly the immeasurable celestial beings, dragon-kings, yakṣas, gandharvas, asuras, garuḍas, kiṃnaras, mahoragas, humans and non-humans, and monks, nuns, laymen, laywomen, those seeking śrāvaka-enlightenment, those seeking pratyekabuddha-enlightenment, those seeking Buddh...

The Buddha now elaborates the prophecy and protection in extensive verse, emphasizing the supreme difficulty and supreme importance of dharma-teaching:
> *"Whoever wishes to dwell in the Buddha-path*
> *And accomplish naturally perfect wisdom,*
> *Should constantly diligently make offerings*
> *To those who uphold the Lotus Sutra.*
> *Whoever wishes to swiftly obtain*

11.title: Chapter 11: Emergence of Prabhutaratna Stupa
11.content:
Chapter 11: Emergence of Prabhutaratna Stupa

**THE COSMIC MANIFESTATION OF WITNESS** At that moment, before the Buddha, there suddenly appeared a seven-jeweled stupa, five hundred *yojanas* in height and two hundred fifty *yojanas* in length and breadth. This magnificent structure surged up from the earth itself, suspended in space, adorned with countless precious objects beyond enumeration. Five thousand railings surrounded it, with ten thousand million chambers carved into its brilliance. Infinite banners and pennants, woven from the finest silks and golden threads, adorned its surfaces in all directions. Precious bells, numbering in the billions, hung suspended from above, each one resonating with the faintest breath. From all four cardinal directions emanated the most precious fragrances—aromatic sandalwood that filled the entire cosmic universe with its presence.¹ The banners themselves were composed of gold, silver, lapis lazuli, crystal, jade, pearls, and rose-quartz—all seven precious materials unified in a single manifestation. The stupa rose until its apex touched the four divine regions themselves, reaching the palaces of those who govern the sensory worlds. From the thirty-three heavens above, celestial beings rained down the sweet mandāra flowers, scattering them as offerings to this extraordinary stupa.² The numberless classes of celestial beings, dragons, yakṣas, gandharvas, asuras, garuḍas, kinnaras, mahoragas, humans, and non-humans—countless millions upon millions—offered to this stupa every precious gift: flowers, fragrances, garlands, banners, canopies, and musical performances. With profound reverence and exultation, they honored and praised this stupa that had emerged from the depths of the earth. Then from the stupa itself there issued a great voice that proclaimed: \"Excellent! Excellent, Śākyamuni Buddha! You have taught the Dharma of the Bodhisattvas with profound wisdom and equanimity. Your teaching is upheld by all Buddhas. This supreme Lotus Sutra—this wondrous teaching—you present ...

12.title: Chapter 12: Devadatta and Naga Princess
12.content:
Chapter 12: Devadatta and Naga Princess

**THE REDEMPTION OF THE ANTAGONIST; THE INSTANTANEOUS ENLIGHTENMENT OF THE EXCLUDED** At that moment, the Buddha addressed all the Bodhisattvas and the four kinds of celestial and human beings: \"Throughout the incomprehensibly distant past—through countless eons—I have sought this Lotus Sutra without ever becoming weary. During many aeons, I lived as a universal monarch, who made a great vow to seek the supreme enlightenment without ever wavering in resolve. Desiring to completely fulfill the six transcendent perfections, I practiced generosity with the most open heart, never hoarding or grasping.¹ \"I gave without measure: elephants and horses, the seven precious treasures, my kingdoms and cities, wives and sons, servants and attendants. I even offered my head, eyes, bone-marrow, brain, and flesh—my entire body was offered as the cost of obtaining this teaching. During those ages, human life-spans were immeasurable. For the sake of this Dharma, I abandoned my throne and transferred the kingdom to my son. I caused great drums to be struck and proclaimed throughout all directions: 'Who is there who can teach me the Great Vehicle? Whoever explains the supreme teaching to me, I shall serve as their slave and attendant throughout my entire life.' \"At that time, a sage-hermit came before me and said: 'I possess a Great Vehicle called the supreme Lotus Sutra. If you do not rebel against me, I shall unfold its teaching for you.' \"Hearing these words, my heart overflowed with delight and my whole being trembled with joy. I immediately followed that hermit-sage, providing for all his needs. I gathered fruits and drew water. I collected firewood and prepared food. Even more than this—I used my own body as a seat upon which he might rest. With neither weariness in body nor fatigue in mind, I served him continuously for one thousand years, attending diligently to his every need so that nothing was lacking.² \"The monks and disciples must now hear what I will tell you: that hermit...

13.title: Chapter 13: Exhortation to Uphold
13.content:
Chapter 13: Exhortation to Uphold

**THE BODHISATTVAS' VOWS: ACCEPTING THE TRANSMISSION** At that moment, the Bodhisattva Mahāsattva named Medicinal-King—a Great Being of extraordinary compassion—and the Bodhisattva Mahāsattva named Great-Joy-in-Speaking—possessing the voice of great proclamation—together with twenty thousand Bodhisattvas and their retinues, all stood before the Buddha and spoke this pledge: \"World Honored One, we implore you: do not concern yourself with anxiety or doubt. After your extinction, when you have entered into final *parinirvāṇa*, we shall uphold, read, recite, and explain this supreme Dharma-teaching. We shall preserve it, we shall practice it, we shall make offerings to it. \"In the future ages, in the times that are to come, sentient beings in the worlds that follow your passing will have become fewer in wholesome roots and deeper in unwholesome tendencies. Pride and conceit will multiply. They will cling to profit and honor, hungry for recognition and worship. They will increase in destructive, unhealthy dispositions, and they will drift far from liberation and awakening. \"**Though these beings are difficult to teach and transform, we shall arise with great patient endurance. We shall read this Dharma, we shall recite it, we shall explain it and teach it. We shall write it down and preserve it in written form. We shall make every kind of offering to it. We shall not spare our bodies and lives in this sacred work.**\"¹ At that very moment, five hundred arhats who had received the prophecy of future Buddhahood stood before the Buddha and proclaimed: \"World Honored One, after your extinction, we also vow freely and openly that we shall travel to different lands and teach this supreme Dharma extensively throughout many realms.\"² Then eight thousand men and women practitioners—both monks and lay followers who had received the prophecy of Buddhahood—rose from their seats, bowed with hands joined in reverence before the Buddha, and made this vow: \"World Honored One, we too vow...

> *We pray the Buddha not to worry—*
> *After the Buddha's final nirvāṇa,*
> *In the fearful evil age to come,*
> *We shall widely proclaim this teaching.*
>
> *There will be foolish people*

14.title: Chapter 14: Peaceful Practice
14.content:
Chapter 14: Peaceful Practice

**THE FOUR CONDITIONS FOR SAFE DHARMA-TEACHING** At that time, Mañjuśrī, the Bodhisattva of supreme wisdom and the Dharma-Prince, addressed the Buddha: \"World Honored One, these Bodhisattvas are indeed most extraordinary, rarely encountered. They possess great respect for the Buddha and profound commitment. They generate great vows for the future. In those evil ages to come, they wish to teach and proclaim this supreme Lotus Sutra. \"World Honored One, how shall these Bodhisattva Mahāsattvas, in those evil ages yet to come, be enabled to teach this supreme Sutra? How shall they do so with confidence and without timidity?\"¹ The Buddha replied to Mañjuśrī: \"If any Bodhisattva Mahāsattva desires to teach this supreme Lotus Sutra in the evil ages yet to come, they must dwell firmly established in four essential practices. What are these four? **First: Establishing oneself in the Bodhisattva's dwelling-place and associations.** Mañjuśrī, if a Bodhisattva Mahāsattva wishes to teach this supreme Sutra in the evil ages, they must establish themselves upon the ground of patience, becoming gentle, yielding, and harmonious. Their heart shall not be suddenly startled or disturbed by difficulties. Moreover, regarding all teachings, they shall not practice attachment or discrimination. Rather, they shall perceive all dharmas as they truly are—not inverted, not unstable, not regressing, not transforming—remaining like empty space, possessing nothing whatsoever.² \"Mañjuśrī, what is meant by 'the Bodhisattva's association' or proper companions? It means the Bodhisattva shall not associate closely with kings, princes, ministers, or officials. They shall not keep company with those who practice false teachings, heretics, or various ascetics. They shall not spend time with those who create worldly compositions glorifying other texts. They shall not befriend those who practice destructive amusements or wrestling matches and various entertainments.³ \"Furthermore, they shall not associate ...

15.title: Chapter 15: Emergence of Bodhisattvas
15.content:
Chapter 15: Emergence of Bodhisattvas

**THE COSMIC DISCLOSURE: INFINITE DISCIPLES APPEAR** At that moment, the Bodhisattva Mahāsattvas from countless worlds beyond—more numerous than the sands of eight Ganges Rivers—rose from their seats. With joined palms in reverence, they addressed the Buddha: \"World Honored One, if you would grant us permission, after your extinction we shall remain in this Sahā world-realm. We shall diligently apply ourselves with great care and effort. We shall uphold, read, recite, write, and make offerings to this supreme Sutra. We shall proclaim it extensively throughout this realm.\" At that moment, the World Honored One addressed all the assembled Bodhisattva Mahāsattvas: \"Stop, good children. There is no need for you to protect and preserve this teaching. Why is this so? **In my Sahā world-realm, there are already six hundred thousand Ganges' worth of Bodhisattva Mahāsattvas.** Each of these Bodhisattvas possesses six hundred thousand Ganges' worth of attendants and retinues. \"All of these beings shall be able, after my extinction, to protect, read, recite, and extensively teach this supreme Sutra.\" --- **THE EARTH RESPONDS: THE COSMIC ASSEMBLY EMERGES** At the moment the Buddha spoke these words, **the entire three-thousand-fold thousand-fold world-system trembled and split open.** From within the fissures, there emerged without number countless millions upon millions of Bodhisattva Mahāsattvas—**an utterly immeasurable multitude, all rising forth simultaneously from beneath this very Sahā world-realm.** All of these Bodhisattvas manifested bodies of golden radiance. Each possessed the thirty-two marks of a Buddha. Each was surrounded by measureless light. They had been dwelling in the empty space beneath this Sahā world-realm, and from their dwelling-places they rose upward. These Bodhisattvas, hearing the voice of Śākyamuni Buddha speaking from above, emerged from below. Each of these Bodhisattvas served as a leader and guide directing multitudes. Each brought with them si...

16.title: Chapter 16: Buddha's Eternal Lifespan
16.content:
Chapter 16: Buddha's Eternal Lifespan

**THE TRIPLE REQUEST: PREPARING FOR REVELATION** At that moment, the Buddha addressed all the Bodhisattvas and the entire great assembly: \"Good children, you must now have complete faith in the Tathāgata's truthful words.\" A second time, he addressed the great assembly: \"Good children, you must now have complete faith in the Tathāgata's truthful words.\" A third time, he addressed the great assembly: \"Good children, you must now have complete faith in the Tathāgata's truthful words.\" At that moment, the assembled Bodhisattva multitudes, with Maitreya at the fore, joined their palms before the Buddha and spoke: \"World Honored One, we only pray that you will teach us. We shall place complete faith in the Buddha's words.\" They made this request once. Again they spoke: \"World Honored One, we only pray that you will teach us. We shall place complete faith in the Buddha's words.\" --- **THE REVELATION: THE BUDDHA'S INCONCEIVABLE LIFESPAN** At that moment, the World Honored One, knowing that the Bodhisattvas had made three requests without ceasing, addressed them, saying: \"Listen carefully to what I shall now reveal to you: **the Tathāgata's secret and supernatural power.** All the beings in the worlds—celestial and human, as well as asuras—believe and imagine that the present Śākyamuni Buddha left the Śākya palace, departed from the Śākya clan, traveled not far from the city of Gayā, sat upon the enlightenment seat, and there attained supreme, perfect enlightenment. \"**But hear this truth, good children: I have in reality been a Buddha for an immeasurable, incalculable number of eons—far beyond what could be expressed as hundred, thousand, ten-thousand, million, billion *asamkhyeya* eons of time.**\" --- **THE MATHEMATICAL PARABLE: WORLDS AS DUST PARTICLES** \"Let me give you an illustration, good children. Suppose there existed five hundred thousand million billion *asamkhyeya* three-thousand-fold thousand-fold world-systems. Further suppose someone were to grind all these w...

17.title: Chapter 17: Discrimination of Merits
17.content:
Chapter 17: Discrimination of Merits

*分別功德品第十七*

At that time, the great assembly gathered around the Buddha heard his revelation of the Tathāgata's eternal lifespan—that immeasurable, incalculable eons have passed since he first attained enlightenment. Countless bodhisattvas, beginning with Maitreya, experienced tremendous benefit from this teaching. Incalculable aeons of beings obtained the spiritual threshold of anuttara-samyak-sambodhi; thousands of times that number of great bodhisattvas gained the dharma-gate of dhāraṇī-hearing; entire assemblies whose numbers equal the dust-particles of a world-realm achieved unrestricted eloquence in explaining dharma; other assemblies numbering like the dust-grains of three thousand great thousand-worlds obtained hundreds of millions upon millions of wheel-turning mantric formulas; three thousand world-realms' worth of great bodhisattvas turned the irreversible dharma-wheel; twice that number developed the dharma-wheel of purity; the bodhisattva-assembly of a thousand worlds would attain supreme enlightenment in eight succeeding lifetimes; four-world-realm assemblies in four lifetimes; three-world-realm assemblies in three; two-world-realm assemblies in two; one-world-realm assemblies in one remaining lifetime; eight complete world-realms' worth of beings awakened the incomparable resolve for supreme enlightenment.
The Buddha declared to Maitreya: "When I spoke this teaching concerning the Tathāgata's eternal lifespan, the merit obtained by beings who developed even a single moment of authentic understanding would be immeasurable and infinite. If a virtuous man or woman devoted himself or herself to practicing the five perfections—generosity, moral discipline, patience, energetic effort, and meditation—through eighty million billion nayuta eons in order to attain incomparable supreme enlightenment, the merit obtained from such practice across all these eons would not equal one-hundredth, one-thousandth, one-hundred-thousandth, one-billion-fold of the merit gained by a single instant of authentic understanding regarding the Tathāgata's eternal lifespan. The disparity is such that even enumeration and analogy fail to capture it.
"Listen further, Maitreya. When one hears of the Tathāgata's eternal lifespan and genuinely comprehends its meaning, the merit obtained is boundless, awakening the Tathāgata's incomparable wisdom. How much greater then when one extensively learns this sutra, teaches it to others, maintains it personally, or writes it out with one's own hand, embellishing it with flowers, fragrant oils, garlands, silk banners, jeweled canopies, and precious incense-vessels burning incense of immeasurable value? Such a person obtains merit of infinite and boundless measure, capable of generating the wisdom of all phenomena.
"When virtuous men and women hear my proclamation of the Tathāgata's eternal lifespan and develop profound, heartfelt understanding, they directly perceive the Buddha dwelling eternally on Vulture Peak Mountain, surrounded by great bodhisattvas and assemblies of śrāvakas, explaining the dharma. Furthermore, they behold this Sahā world-realm: its ground composed of lapis lazuli, level and smooth; eight roads marked with grades of gold; rows of precious trees; towers, pavilions, and observation halls all manifested in the seven jewels; bodhisattva assemblies inhabiting these places. Whoever is able to perceive in this manner possesses marks of profound authentic understanding.
"Furthermore, after the Tathāgata's passing, should one hear this sutra and neither reject nor disparage it, instead generating a mind of sincere rejoicing, understand that such a being has already established marks of profound understanding. What need be said of those who actually read it aloud, maintain it, or practice accordingly? These people carry the Tathāgata atop their heads. I declare, Maitreya, that such virtuous men and women need not establish stupas or construct monastic dwellings for the support of the sangha. Why is this? Those virtuous men and women who receive and maintain, read and recite this sutra have already established stupas, constructed monastic dwellings, and provided support to the sangha. They have, in effect, raised seven-jeweled stupas honoring the Tathāgata's relics, reaching toward the Brahma realms, hung with jeweled banners and numberless precious bells, decorated with flowers, fragrant oils, garlands, and powdered incenses. Through immeasurable thousands of millions of eons, they have continuously offered such worship.
"I declare, Maitreya: after my passing, should one hear this sutra and be able to maintain it—whether by writing it themselves or arranging for it to be written—they thereby construct a monastic dwelling, a great temple of sandalwood wood with thirty-two halls, eight palm-trees high, ornate and sublime. Thousands of millions of monastics dwell therein, supplied with all necessities: gardens, bathing pools, pathways for circumambulation, meditation caves, robes, food, beds, medicinal preparations, and all requisite pleasures. Such monastic dwellings in their diversity number countless thousands of millions.

18.title: Chapter 18: Merit of Rejoicing
18.content:
Chapter 18: Merit of Rejoicing

*隨喜功德品第十八* At that time, Maitreya Bodhisattva approached the Buddha with reverent demeanor and inquired: \"World-Honored One, when beings hear this Lotus Sutra and develop a mind of sincere rejoicing, what measure of merit do they acquire?\" The Buddha replied to Maitreya: \"After the Tathāgata's passing, should a bhikṣu, bhikṣuṇī, upāsaka, or upāsikā—indeed, any wise being whether elder or youth—hear this sutra and sincerely rejoice, understanding its meaning, they should proceed from that assembly to other locations: monastic dwellings, open spaces, towns, villages, highways, or fields. There they shall explain this dharma to father, mother, relatives, or knowledgeable companions, conveying what they have heard according to their understanding. These listeners, upon hearing, shall themselves generate rejoicing and communicate this joy to still others. In this manner, from person to person, the transmission continues until the fiftieth recipient is reached. \"Maitreya, observe the merit of this fiftieth virtuous man or woman who has received the joy of the sutra through sequential transmission. I shall now elucidate it for you. \"Consider four hundred million billion nayuta world-realms populated with six-path beings of all types—those born from eggs, wombs, moisture, and transformation; those with form and formless; those with consciousness and unconscious; those neither conscious nor unconscious; those with no feet, two feet, four feet, or multiple feet—in essence, all categories of sentient life. Suppose a great benefactor, wishing to acquire merit, provides to each of these innumerable beings whatever objects delight them, whatever brings joy and satisfaction. To each being, he distributes treasures filling the entire continent of Jambudvīpa: gold, silver, lapis lazuli, crystal, agate, coral, amber, and all precious jewels. Moreover, he provides elephants, horses, carriages, and palaces constructed of seven jewels—towered mansions and pavilions. This great benefacto...

*At that time, the Tathāgata wished to restate this meaning through verse:*
A person hearing this dharma in the assembly,
Even a single verse, with sincere rejoicing,
Teaches it to another, who also rejoices,
The transmission continuing through fifty successive recipients—
The fifty-fold retransmission holds merit of this nature:

19.title: Chapter 19: Dharma Teacher Merits
19.content:
Chapter 19: Dharma Teacher Merits

*法師功德品第十九* At that time, the Buddha addressed Avalokiteśvara the Bodhisattva of Constant Exertion: \"When a virtuous man or woman maintains this Lotus Sutra—whether by reading it, reciting it, explaining it, or writing it—that person shall acquire eight hundred eye-perfections, one thousand two hundred ear-perfections, eight hundred nose-perfections, one thousand two hundred tongue-perfections, eight hundred body-perfections, and one thousand two hundred mind-perfections. Through these perfections, the six sense-organs shall become completely purified. \"The virtuous man or woman, having such purification, shall perceive through the naturally-born physical eye—unenhanced by supernatural power—the three thousand great thousand-worlds in all their extent and interior. They perceive mountains and forests, great rivers and seas, extending downward to Avīci hell and upward to the Akaniṣṭha realm. All beings inhabiting these realms, together with their karmic deeds, causes, and destinies, the virtuous person sees and knows completely. \"Furthermore, Avalokiteśvara, when a virtuous man or woman maintains this sutra—whether reading, reciting, explaining, or writing it—they acquire one thousand two hundred ear-perfections. The naturally-born ear, without supernatural augmentation, shall hear the three thousand great thousand-worlds in all their dimensions. They shall perceive: \"All animal sounds—the trumpeting of elephants, neighing of horses, bellowing of cattle, bleating of sheep, and cries of other beasts. The sounds of carriages and carts. The cries of human suffering and lamentation, the sounds of sorrow and anguish. The sounds of spiral shells and drums, bells and chimes, flutes and pipes, stringed instruments and musical instruments of every description. The sounds of song and speech, the voices of men and women, of young boys and young girls. Dharmic sounds and non-dharmic sounds. Sounds of suffering and sounds of joy. The sounds of common beings and the voices of sages...

*At that time, the Tathāgata wished to restate this meaning through verse:*
When a person speaks this sutra
Before a great assembly without fear,
Listen to the perfections they obtain:
Eight hundred eye-perfections they achieve,
Granting the eyes extraordinary clarity.

20.title: Chapter 20: Never Despiser
20.content:
Chapter 20: Never Despiser

*常不輕菩薩品第二十* At that time, the Buddha addressed the Bodhisattva Mahāsthāmaprāpta: \"You should understand that among those who maintain the Lotus Sutra, should any individual curse, revile, or disparage such a keeper of the sutra, the karmic consequences shall be severe, as described previously. But understand equally: those who maintain this Lotus Sutra thereby acquire the perfected senses mentioned—eye-purity, ear-purity, nose-purity, tongue-purity, body-purity, and mind-purity. \"Mahāsthāmaprāpta, in ages long past—across immeasurable, incalculable eons—there existed a Buddha named Bhaiṣajya-rāja (the Medicine King), the Tathāgata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Awakened One, the One Perfectly Accomplished in Knowledge and Conduct, the Sugata, the Knower of the World, the Unsurpassable Guide, the Tamer of the Untamed, the Teacher of Gods and Humans, the Buddha, the World-Honored One. His lifespan extended across four million billion nayuta eons. In his world, an age called the Age of Prosperity prevailed, and his realm was named the Great Achievement. \"The Buddha Bhaiṣajya-rāja taught the dharma to gods, humans, and asuras. To those seeking arhatship, he explained the dharma of the four truths, enabling them to transcend birth, old age, sickness, and death, ultimately reaching the final peace of nirvāṇa. To those seeking solitary-buddha realization, he taught the dharma of dependent origination in twelve aspects. To the bodhisattvas and all beings, he explained the dharma of the six perfections, ultimately leading them to perfect enlightenment. \"In that age, the Buddha Bhaiṣajya-rāja possessed eighty billion great bodhisattvas and assemblies of seventy-two trillion enlightened śrāvakas. That Buddha's lifespan extended four million billion nayuta eons. The dharma remained as the Buddha's living teaching for a period of years equal in number to the dust-particles of an entire Jambudvīpa continent. The semblance dharma (the era after the Buddha's departure when the form of t...

*At that time, the Tathāgata wished to restate this meaning through verse:*
In ages past, there was a Buddha
Called the Medicine King,
Possessed of supernatural wisdom,
Who guided countless beings.
Gods and humans and asuras alike

21.title: Chapter 21: Tathagata's Supernatural Powers
21.content:
Chapter 21: Tathagata's Supernatural Powers

*如來神力品第二十一* At that time, myriads of bodhisattvas—numbering like the dust-particles of entire world-realms—emerged from beneath the earth. These were bodhisattvas who had previously dwelt in the Sahā world. They approached the Buddha, bowed with their heads to his feet, and addressed him: \"World-Honored One, after you enter final nirvāṇa, in the lands where your various emanations have taught and subsequently passed away, we shall extensively proclaim this Lotus Sutra. Why? Because we ourselves desire to obtain this true, pure, supreme dharma. We shall receive it, maintain it, read and recite it, explain it, and offer reverent worship to it.\" At that moment, the Tathāgata revealed his great supernatural powers before all assembled—before myriads of old bodhisattvas dwelling in the Sahā world, before myriads of monks and nuns, before male and female lay followers, before gods, dragons, and all types of supernatural beings. The Buddha extended his broad, long tongue upward until it reached the Brahma heavens, and from every pore of his body, he emitted innumerable rays of light, illuminating all ten directions of the world-system. All the precious trees beneath which were seated the Buddhas from the ten directions, as well as Śākyamuni Buddha and the eternally present Buddha (Prabhūtaratna), similarly extended their broad, long tongues and emitted vast rays of light. The display of supernatural power continued for one hundred thousand years. Afterward, the Buddha and all those Buddhas withdrew their tongues. At that moment, all the Buddhas produced a single sound of coughing and a simultaneous finger-snap. These two sounds echoed throughout the ten directions of all world-systems. In all those world-systems, the very earth underwent six kinds of trembling: trembling, quaking, roaring, cracking, heaving, and surging upward. Through the Buddha's supernatural power, all beings throughout the ten directions perceived this Sahā world-realm: they saw the endless precious tr...

*At that time, the Tathāgata wished to restate this meaning through verse:*
All the Buddhas, saviors of the world,
Possess great supernatural powers,
Manifesting boundless miraculous deeds
To delight all sentient beings.
The tongue-faculty extends to the Brahma realms,

22.title: Chapter 22: Entrustment
22.content:
Chapter 22: Entrustment

*囑累品第二十二* At that time, Śākyamuni Buddha rose from his dharma-seat, revealed great supernatural powers, and with his right hand touched the heads of innumerable bodhisattvas, speaking these words: \"Through countless, incalculable eons, I have cultivated and perfected the supreme dharma of unsurpassed, perfect enlightenment. Now I entrust this dharma to all of you. You should all unite in mind and widely proclaim this dharma, causing it to increase and flourish.\" Thus did the Buddha touch the heads of the bodhisattva assembly three times, each time declaring: \"Through countless, incalculable eons, I have cultivated and perfected the supreme dharma of unsurpassed, perfect enlightenment. Now I entrust this dharma to all of you. You should receive and maintain it, widely proclaim it in all realms, allowing all beings to hear it completely. Why? Because I possess great compassion, complete absence of stinginess or miserliness, and no fear whatsoever. I am able to bestow upon all sentient beings the Buddha's wisdom, the Tathāgata's wisdom, and the spontaneously arising wisdom. All the Tathāgatas are great benefactors to all sentient beings. You too should follow the example of the Tathāgata, abandoning all stinginess. In the future age, when virtuous men and women who possess faith in the Tathāgata's wisdom approach you, you should widely expound this Lotus Sutra to them so that they may hear it fully. For what reason? In order that they might attain Buddha-wisdom. \"Should any sentient beings not believe, not receive, and not maintain this sutra, then you should guide them through the remaining profound dharmas taught by the Tathāgata, demonstrating benefits to them through skillful teachings, giving joy and delight so that they gradually attain the bodhisattva path. All of you should thereby repay the graciousness of all the Tathāgatas.\" At that moment, hearing the Buddha's instructions, all the bodhisattva assembly experienced profound joy that pervaded their entire bei...

*At that time, the Tathāgata wished to restate this meaning through verse:*
All the Buddhas, saviors of the world,
Dwelling in great supernatural power,
For the sake of the bodhisattva path,
Now entrust this dharma to you all.
My Buddha-dharma, accumulated across eons,

23.title: Chapter 23: Medicine King Bodhisattva
23.content:
Chapter 23: Medicine King Bodhisattva

*藥王菩薩本事品第二十三* At that time, Śākyamuni Buddha addressed the Bodhisattva Prabhūtaratna: \"Inquire of me regarding the Medicine King Bodhisattva's original practice. How did this bodhisattva cultivate? What dharma does he teach? Pray tell us the history of this one we honor.\" Buddha replied: \"In ages past, beyond measurement in incalculable eons, there existed a Buddha named the Lord of Purity of the Sun and Moon—the Tathāgata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Awakened One, the One Perfectly Accomplished in Knowledge and Conduct, the Sugata, the Knower of the World, the Unsurpassable Guide, the Tamer of the Untamed, the Teacher of Gods and Humans, the Buddha, the World-Honored One. He possessed eighty billion great bodhisattvas and an assembly of seventy-two trillion enlightened śrāvakas. That Buddha's lifespan spanned four million billion nayuta eons. The true dharma remained in that realm for a period measured in years equal to the dust-particles of a continent. The semblance dharma likewise persisted through such measure. \"In that realm, there existed a bodhisattva named All-Beings-Are-Delighted-by-the-Sight—a bodhisattva who had long cultivated the roots of virtue, offered reverence to innumerable Buddhas, and perfected profound wisdom. This bodhisattva had achieved numerous samādhis: the samādhi of displaying all forms, the samādhi of dharma-blossoming, the samādhi of pure virtue, the samādhi of celestial play, and countless others. \"At that time, the Buddha Sun-Moon-Pure-Lord taught the Dharma-Blossom Sutra to all sentient beings. All-Beings-Are-Delighted-by-the-Sight heard this teaching and, wishing to demonstrate his understanding, entered the samādhi of displaying all forms. From within this samādhi, he caused himself to manifest in an ocean of amrita (divine nectar) within the void itself. Having perceived one hundred thousand kinds of precious flowers blooming in that ocean, he declared: 'The dharma I now perceive through the Dharma-Blossom Sutra is so profound! I vo...

*At that time, the Tathāgata wished to restate this meaning through verse:*
This dharma-blossom is supreme,
Most difficult to encounter,
Among all the teachings I have proclaimed,
It stands foremost.
Consider the four oceans with all their waters—

24.title: Chapter 24: Wonderful Sound Bodhisattva
24.content:
Chapter 24: Wonderful Sound Bodhisattva

*妙音菩薩品第二十四* At that time, Śākyamuni Buddha emitted the light-marks of universal brilliance from between his eyebrows, illuminating to the east one hundred eight hundred million nayuta realms. Beyond that number of worlds, there existed a realm named Pure-Light-Adorned. In that realm dwelt a Buddha named Pure-Lotus-Celestial-Wisdom-Tathāgata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Awakened One, the One Perfectly Accomplished in Knowledge and Conduct, the Sugata, the Knower of the World, the Unsurpassable Guide, the Tamer of the Untamed, the Teacher of Gods and Humans, the Buddha, the World-Honored One. He was surrounded and honored by innumerable and incalculable assemblies of great bodhisattvas as he expounded the dharma. At that time, the light from the Buddha's eyebrow-mark illuminated the Pure-Light-Adorned realm, causing that Buddha and his assembly to perceive Śākyamuni Buddha's dharma-transmission. Within that realm dwelt a bodhisattva named Wonderful-Sound, one who had long cultivated roots of virtue, paid reverence to countless billions of Buddhas, and achieved profound wisdom. This bodhisattva had perfected eighteen kinds of dharma-gates (meditative absorptions and capacities), including the Marvelous-Banner Samādhi, the Dharma-Blossom Samādhi, the Pure-Virtue Samādhi, the Celestial-Play Samādhi, the Boundless Samādhi, the Wisdom-Seal Samādhi, the Gate of Understanding-All-Beings'-Language, the Samādhi of Gathering All Merits, the Pure Samādhi, the Divine-Play-Through-Powers Samādhi, the Wisdom-Torch Samādhi, the Sovereign-Adornment Samādhi, the Pure-Illumination Samādhi, the Treasury-of-Purity Samādhi, the Unshared Samādhi, the Solar-Revolution Samādhi, and countless billions of other dharma-gates. When the Buddha's light illuminated this bodhisattva's body, Wonderful-Sound immediately addressed his Buddha, Pure-Lotus-Celestial-Wisdom: \"World-Honored One, I perceive that the light from Śākyamuni Buddha's form reaches here. I wish to journey to the Sahā world-realm, to p...

*At that time, the Buddha wished to restate this meaning through verse:*
From the eastern realm, beyond reckoning,
From the Pure-Light-Adorned World,
There came a bodhisattva named Wonderful-Sound,
Together with eighty-four thousand beings.
He cultivated virtue in the ancient past,

25.title: Chapter 25: Avalokiteshvara
25.content:
Chapter 25: Avalokiteshvara

*觀世音菩薩普門品第二十五* At that time, the Bodhisattva Boundless-Intention rose from his seat, bowed respectfully with his head to the Buddha's feet, and posed this inquiry: \"World-Honored One, I wish to ask: For what reason is the Bodhisattva Avalokiteśvara called by this name?\" The Buddha replied: \"Excellent question, Boundless-Intention. If countless billions of sentient beings experiencing suffering hear the name Avalokiteśvara and call upon this bodhisattva with sincere intention, the Bodhisattva Avalokiteśvara will immediately perceive the sound of their invocation. That being will at once gain liberation. For this reason, this bodhisattva is named Avalokiteśvara—the One Who Perceives the World's Sounds of Suffering. \"If a being faces great fire and calls upon Avalokiteśvara, the flames cannot burn such a person, because the bodhisattva's power of wisdom prevents the fire from destroying them. If one is swept away by a great flood and cries out to Avalokiteśvara, one will suddenly find oneself in shallow water. If a hundred thousand billion sentient beings venture onto the great ocean seeking treasures—silver, lapis lazuli, crystal, agate, coral, amber, pearls and other jewels—and their boat is caught in a black wind and driven toward the realm of the rākṣasa demons, a single person among them calling upon Avalokiteśvara will rescue all from the danger of the demons. \"If someone faces impending execution and invokes Avalokiteśvara, the executioner's weapons will shatter into fragments and the condemned person will escape. If a being is bound with chains or shackles and calls upon this bodhisattva, all restraints will break free, and that person will attain liberation. If a region is filled with countless night-demons and rākṣasas intending to cause harm, and they hear the name Avalokiteśvara invoked, these harmful beings will not dare even look upon the invocant with malice, much less cause injury. \"Moreover, Boundless-Intention, if a being harbors excessive lust and co...

*At that time, Boundless-Intention wished to restate these teachings in verse:*
O World-Honored One of wondrous form,
I now inquire of you again:
Why is this bodhisattva called by this name?
What is the source of Avalokiteśvara's designation?
The Buddha replied to Boundless-Intention:

26.title: Chapter 26: Dharani Protective Formulas
26.content:
Chapter 26: Dharani Protective Formulas

*陀羅尼品第二十六* At that time, the Bodhisattva Medicine King rose from his seat, bowed respectfully, and addressed the Buddha: \"World-Honored One, if virtuous men and women receive and maintain this Dharma-Blossom Sutra, whether they read it, recite it, understand it, or write it out, how much merit would they obtain?\" The Buddha replied to Medicine King: \"If a virtuous man or woman were to make offerings to eight hundred million billion nayuta Ganges-river-sand-number of Buddhas, what do you think? Would they accumulate immeasurable merit?\" Medicine King responded: \"Immeasurable indeed, World-Honored One.\" The Buddha declared: \"If a virtuous man or woman receives and maintains this sutra—even simply receiving one four-line verse, reading it aloud, understanding its meaning, and practicing according to it—the merit accumulated would be equally immeasurable.\" Then Medicine King Bodhisattva addressed the Buddha: \"World-Honored One, I now offer to all dharma-teachers the protective mantra-formula (dharani), so that those who recite it will be protected and guarded.\" Then Medicine King spoke the protective mantra: *\"anale manale maṇī maṇī manṭhī jaliṭe śarī śarītavai vāntī devi muktī mutali āvai savalī alalī avai arkali ala utkaniṭi sāntdevī śarali tāraṇī ālugṛbhavānavai nilavittā ālabhāvantī iṭṭchayā ālaṭalidevī nirittha niritāvahī iṭṭī kheme āloga bhavāsabhathai damarpaḷi samugamahasrahī buddhavai vibhisani nībatthī ālabhuddhapalitrī damarābaliśudade gamarābaliśudade sambhavai nilambaṭai dhamarabaliśudade\"* Medicine King declared: \"World-Honored One, this mantra-formula of protection has been spoken by sixty-two billion Ganges-river-sand-number of Buddhas. Any who harm this dharma-teacher through this protection would thereby harm all those Buddhas.\" At that time, the Buddha praised Medicine King: \"Excellent! Excellent, Medicine King! Through compassion for the dharma-teachers, you have spoken this protective formula. This brings immeasurable benefit to all sentient beings....

*At that time, the Buddha wished to restate this meaning through verse:*
When the dharma-teachers maintain this sutra,
All the bodhisattvas offer their protection,
Medicine King proclaims his mantra,
Courageous-Giver adds his power.
The four Heavenly Kings—

27.title: Chapter 27: Wonderful Adornment King
27.content:
Chapter 27: Wonderful Adornment King

*妙莊嚴王本事品第二十七* At that time, the Buddha addressed the assembled great audience: \"In ages long past—spanning incalculable eons beyond measurement—there existed a Buddha named Cloud-Thunder-Sound-Celestial-Wisdom, the Tathāgata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Awakened One, the One Perfectly Accomplished in Knowledge and Conduct, the Sugata, the Knower of the World, the Unsurpassable Guide, the Tamer of the Untamed, the Teacher of Gods and Humans, the Buddha, the World-Honored One. His realm was named Radiance-Flourishing, and the age was called Joyful-Perception. \"In that realm, there was a king named Wonderful-Adornment. His queen was named Pure-Virtue. The king had two sons: one was named Pure-Treasury, the other Pure-Vision. Both sons possessed great supernatural powers, deep karmic-roots, long-cultivated merit, and profound wisdom. They had perfected the six perfections (generosity, discipline, patience, effort, meditation, wisdom), bodhisattva-methods of skillful means, and compassion-love. They had also mastered countless samādhis and absorbed the thirty-seven aids-to-enlightenment. \"At that time, Buddha Cloud-Thunder-Sound-Celestial-Wisdom wished to transform the Wonderful-Adornment King and to liberate all beings in his realm, so he expounded the Dharma-Blossom Sutra. The two princes approached their mother and said: 'Dear Mother, we wish to go to the Buddha Cloud-Thunder-Sound-Celestial-Wisdom to pay reverence, draw near, make offerings, and receive the teachings. We earnestly desire to hear the Dharma-Blossom Sutra.' \"Their mother replied: 'Your father, the king, is deeply attached to the teachings of external religions and cannot easily accept the dharma. You must first convince your father to go with us.' \"The two princes responded respectfully: 'Mother, we understand that our father has incorrect views. We shall show him miracles so that his heart becomes pure and clear. Then he will listen to us and agree to go to the Buddha.' \"Thereupon, the two pure sons, des...

*We beseech you, Mother, to grant us permission—*
*To leave the household and become śramaṇa monks.*
*The Buddhas are exceedingly difficult to encounter;*
*We wish to follow the Buddha in study and practice.*
*Like the udumbara flower*
*Blooming only once in vast ages,*

28.title: Chapter 28: Samantabhadra's Encouragement
28.content:
Chapter 28: Samantabhadra's Encouragement

*普賢菩薩勸發品第二十八* At that time, the Bodhisattva Samantabhadra (the Universally-Worthy Bodhisattva) approached the Buddha with his innumerable, boundless, incalculable bodhisattva-retinue from the east, manifesting his transcendent power and magnificence, renowned throughout the ten directions. Wherever he passed, the ground trembled with six kinds of motion, precious lotus flowers rained down, and hundreds of millions of kinds of celestial music played spontaneously. Samantabhadra arrived at Vulture Peak Mountain, bowed with his head to the feet of Śākyamuni Buddha, circumambulated him seven times, and addressed him: \"World-Honored One, in my realm called Precious-Glory, I heard, from far away, that this Sahā world-realm teaches the Dharma-Blossom Sutra. Together with innumerable bodhisattvas, I have journeyed here to listen. I earnestly request that you teach this dharma. If there are virtuous men or women who will receive, maintain, read, recite, remember, learn, and practice this Dharma-Blossom Sutra after the Tathāgata's passage, how will they accomplish this? How will they protect themselves?\" The Buddha replied to Samantabhadra: \"If virtuous men and women are to receive this dharma after the Tathāgata's passing, they must accomplish four conditions. First, they must be protected by all the Buddhas. Second, they must plant the roots of virtue. Third, they must enter the assembly of the determined. Fourth, they must awaken the mind to rescue all sentient beings. Those virtuous men and women who accomplish these four conditions will definitely obtain this Dharma-Blossom Sutra after the Tathāgata's passage. \"Samantabhadra, in the degenerate age five hundred years after the Tathāgata's passage, among those who maintain this sutra, I shall guard and protect them, relieving them of all afflictions. I will ensure that no spirits, demons, demon-children, demon-women, demon-followers, demon-possessed individuals, yakṣas, rākṣasas, kumbhāṇḍas, piśācas, yakṣa-spirits, rich-de...

*At that time, the Tathāgata wished to restate this meaning through verse:*
The Universally-Worthy Bodhisattva,
Pure-hearted and compassionate,
Has arrived from his distant realm,
Leading countless bodhisattvas in his retinue.
